you and thanks very much for
and so I would say that I remember years ago joy is saying to me that when Paul
Farmer was invited to talk and and he couldn't go and she would go in his face that it was always a little challenging you know to to kind of meet the
expectations so one thing that I think joy really set well was encouraging
people to really interact and to ask questions and to raise points and to you know bring up issues that they are
themselves are familiar with so I want that to be a way to actually make this lecture work as well and hopefully going
forward with the other lectures so feel free to put your hand up and raise points and we'll we'll work around that
and you know that way I think be more exciting so while I'll ask a few questions as well hopefully along the way that well
we get some good answers from what I want to do really was to follow on from what joy was talking about and I think
she really did a great job of bringing up the the challenges of providing health care and very resourceful
environments and all the difficulties and the huge problems that have to be overcome to do that but also that one of
the reasons why these problems are being so acute is that the the policies and the strategies that have been used to
support health care and to improve health care haven't always been well designed and I think we you know recognize that there are many aspects
about the the way that we've gone about trying to improve healthcare systems which really weren't suitable for the
environments and for the communities that they are in and this is a real challenge also for the use of technology
and for information systems that we need to be thinking very hard about what are the real needs of people on the ground
and then identifying where those needs relate to access to information as opposed to other fundamental issues like
presence of trained staff access to drugs access to you know basic requirements of life like clean water
and food and so on and I think that there are a number of issues about information systems that are also
somewhat dysfunctional in the way that they've been approached in resource-poor environments and a lot of countries
around the world actually even middle-income in high-income countries and that's something that we're really interested in addressing what I want to
do is really talk about the importance of this question of where information access is is a real challenge and where
it can improving that can really make a difference to the quality of care and in some ways there's there's sort of
two sides to this because on one hand we are looking at situations where someone might need to have access to for example
laboratory data or that the previous medications of the patient's been taking to be able to design their care or to
diagnose that patient more effectively there's also the other side which is that you can't really undo improvements
in quality of care unless you can measure how well you're doing you can't really ensure that the care is actually
being provided and that quality is improving as you initiate different improvements and so there's both the
intervention piece and there's also the measurement piece and needs to interact and interesting and complicated ways so
you know sometimes we may be really monitoring what's happening with other aspects of care and other times we may be that the information system may be
the main intervention so I also like to do a little bit of review of some of the systems that have actually been
developed over the last 10 years a lot from our my group and colleagues and friends around the world and also other
organizations and systems and particularly to focus on evaluation data and I think this has been one of the
greatest missing pieces in a lot of the projects around the world but although fairly large investments to be made
thank some cases very large investments to be made in information systems we really don't have a good evidence base
for what is actually working what isn't we're getting it now but it's taken a long time so I'll kick off by talking a
bit about global health informatics or global health which is the other term that people use a lot I'll talk about
the EMR system in Peru that we developed the pollens in Health EMR and then talk about a primeras as a platform and how
we've actually used that system in Rwanda and I'd learned like to review some of the other EF projects and
lessons learned from these experiences over the years oops so what was the kind
of the original problem that was set when I started with pH just over ten years ago it was really the question was
can treatment of HIV and in this case particularly drugs in TB be delivered in
settings with limited or absent infrastructure and so I think Joya really went long way to addressing that
question in terms of how do you design a system will work to provide ambulatory care for T MDR TB and to get the prices
of drugs down and but then the question was how do you then scale that so I started there were
a bit very maybe about a hundred patients who've been treated in Peru for MDR TB or or who were on treatment and
we wanted to aim for tens of thousands of patients so how is that the same is
that just a case of incrementally increasing that what you're doing or is that qualitatively different and do you
need different systems and I think really the argument made then and I certainly would support that now is that
you cannot treat ten thousand people in the same way you can treat 50 or hundred people you need a different way of doing
things and so information systems of one of those pieces the other thing we wanted to do was to scale this system
too many sites and also expanded over time so that it became a long term project with many new people working on
it rather than just a small core group of enthusiasts who did it really kind of designed the original system and we're
needed to do so to ensure that they were good outcomes and that the cost was manageable and I say manageable leaving
it somewhat vague because we can come back and talk about what that means one of the interesting things when we
started was that people thought we were basically nuts the idea of doing information systems in Haiti or Peru or
Rwanda you know the people really said you know you guys are crazy I think that was the Clinton Foundation actually and so we had a slide refused
to show people for a while until they eventually decided maybe it wasn't such a bad idea over the last couple of years
we've really seen a big change in in kind of people's thinking about this it came a little bit from a whole series of
developments are going on such as the need for better global health delivery and a recognition that the delivery
process of care is one of the key problems that we face that there are technologies and you know there there
are approaches to health care and tools and drugs and so on that will allow everybody in the world to have a decent
quality of life but most people are a large portion people are not getting full access to that so delivery is a
critical part of it there's also obviously increased funding for Global Health particular with the Global Fund
and PEPFAR and other agencies recognizing you know with epidemics like
HIV and MDR TB that there needs to be better investment in in both the the
direct care but also in the and the infrastructure and then there's also fortunately better lower-cost
technologies more robust low-power easier tools to use than when we started
and one of the things that kind of spurred this off was probably the meeting in Bellagio about two and a half years ago which was hosted by the
Rockefeller Foundation and and we ran a session on electronic medical record systems and looking at how these systems
could actually be improved and scaled in developing countries so you had a little
bit well quite a good bit about Partners in Health last week and I just wanted to quickly review the kind of the pH model
of care and how that fits with the way that we've been working with information systems as well so first of all of
course we focus on access to health care to all people whatever the situation or environment we also look at the question
of how do you create long term partnerships rather than just one-off projects that maybe last for a year or
two or three but actually really building these relationships and working with communities and training people and
handing over all of that management as this as the project grows clearly we
have a big focus on community healthcare workers and building that community workforce within each different
environment and training people and so on and clearly another piece that we joi
talked a lot about was the question of addressing the various different causes of disease and the socio-economic causes
of ill health such as lack of food access to clean water housing and so on
and one of the things that I think is particularly relevant to my work is this question of bringing together both the
elite institutions that connect institutions and medical schools and the technology that we have access to in a
place like MIT with the lived experience of people in extremely difficult and challenging environments and looking and
saying well what are the things that we can do that would really help that situation not what is the technology
we've that's worked in the u.s. we can just plunk down there but what are the real problems on the ground and is there some way we could use to actually
innovatively solve those problems and I think that's the approach you really have to take think of you know very very
driven by the problem by the need by the ideas of people actually work in that environment given
I'm sure seen examples of the healthcare community of care because and this is the the accompany
terror in Haiti the person who really walks with this patient through their health and through their management of
their disease providing direct observed therapy to the patient and and this is really one of the key interventions that
have made such a difference in care for HIV and TB when I started this work I
was thinking quite a lot about the work I'd done in the US and in Europe on management of chronic diseases and this
is really a relatively new field so when I was doing medical school I wouldn't like to say exactly how long ago chronic
disease management was still kind of a little bit ad hoc thing there were people who knew how to do it like the diabeetus --tz-- and there were other
people who weren't so good at it and heart disease in particular was not managed well in the community and what
we needed to do was to kind of look at a new model for managing patients so what happened with HIV and drug-resistant TB
but particularly the whole HIV epidemic in Africa was that suddenly we had to build a chronic disease management model
that worked in developing environments in very very difficult environments and the things you need to do there you first of all you need to do case-finding
need to identify the patients and this is you know still very challenging and I'll talk a bit more about this later on you need to make sure they start on the
correct treatment now if it's a simple case of HIV I mean if a HIV is ever
simple then you you should start on probably try immune or some fairly straightforward treatment with one you
know one tablet and that might be a little bit simpler than maybe treating a
second-line case of HIV if you have drugs this in TB while you're talking
about much more complicated treatment the next thing is to ensure that there's a stable and economical supply
medication and that turned out to be one of the really critical things that we've worked on over the years and surprisingly something that improved
incredibly little attention until the last year or two and it's a huge huge problem and a huge limitation to our
ability to treat patients throughout the world we need to ensure compliance of treatment and that's something where the
community health care workers of course are our critical technology if you like in many of the projects and then we also
need to monitor the progress and outcomes these patients to show that they are in fact responding to treatment
to respond problems that occur either drug side effects or probably patients for example who have resistance that are
not responding to the treatment they're on so there are a number of core
functions that we focus on with systems we were building in the first was
clinical care and quality improvement and and this was I think really the core issue we were not just interested in
kind of the public health approach of like what's happening you know sort of in a community it's at a larger community or national level but but how
do you actually address an individual patients treatment the next thing was monitoring reporting and so making sure
that we could act keep track of what was happening and also report to the government and to the funders drug Supply Management which I said you know
kind of really suddenly appeared as a major problem originally in Peru and and also observational research collecting
data that could be used to understand better what was happening and how to improve that so the first example in
that I started in you know again really building on what joy was talking about last week was the treatment of
drug-resistant TB in Peru and and as she said the Peru had a particularly high instance of TB and still does and there
were about 40,000 patients a year getting first line or dot's treatment when I started working there it's a
little bit lower now but it's still pretty significant and over three percent of these patients had drugs in TB and figure is actually hard to
measure and we're doing big big studies at the moment to really try to measure that it accurately and these patients
can require up to nine different drugs to treat them so it's a really complicated thing and it's tailored to
the sensitivity or resistance patterns of the organism that they have so it's not just a case of of standardizing this
process you really have to tailor it to get the best results so what we did was
we built this web-based medical record was based on some projects I was doing with Peter syllabic one of the people
who's running this course a long time ago we they we'd started working on web-based medical records and so when I
started talking to pH about the the needs of the Peru project that seemed to be the right technology people did think
we were crazy to do this but um it worked we started with basically dial-up connection for about a year and the
system was built and basically bilingual and English and span and then we've sort of scaled it over
the years and it's now got over a hundred thousand patient records in it over thirteen thousand have started or
completed treatment for MDR TB and it's the national system for MDR TB for the government the system has a number of
different key areas of data particularly the smears and cultures and drug
sensitivity test results or D STS so remember this will come back to this this is the testing that the
Mycobacterium to see which antibiotics it responds to other lab data like
biochemistry I can a registration form with a previous history and examination
data and previous treatment digital images of chest x-rays which we actually use a special protocol and digital
camera for and then drug regimen data are very key part of the whole process
so having got this thing established we found there were a number of problems and so one lesson I think which I would
like to kind of bounce out to you is when things don't work it's often an opportunity to do something interesting
it's annoying it's someone's dispiriting but when you find a problem it's often
the time when you should take a step back and think what's going on here because that's when we actually you tend to find yourself innovating and coming
up with interesting results so one of the problems we had was that this back to ology data was not very good it was
difficult to get hold off because in the area of lean we were working in their 120 clinics and about 60 of them did
either microscopy for the smears of the Mycobacterium this is from the sputum
samples it says or they did culture in some cases and so each one had its own little logbook into a microscope and
maybe they had the incubator and a guy who was actually reporting this stuff and they were the team would go round
with the notebooks they'd write this stuff down they'd go back to the the clinic the we work with and they would
then put it into a logbook and then that would get entered into the EMR and you can imagine it was just a a really inefficient process probably an
extremely typical process of what actually happens in many places so what we said was well why don't we just use a
Palm Pilot download a list of the patients in the district give that to the to the the team member who is going
to that site and they could then enter into the Palm Pilot and then when they think system when they go back to the clinic
you'll go into a kind of holding area where they could check the smears and cultures and make sure the data was in good quality and then just that would
activate put that into the main record and so working blyer who is working on
his PhD with me at the time did this project was a little really kind of almost like a trial project gonna get
that get started on this the study that he was doing but he turned it into a huge success and what we did was to do
an actual in study of the impact of this system and this was a design where we wanted to look at both historical
controls and contemporary controls so we looked at four clinics who randomized to too early into too late implementation
and then we looked at the the pre data and then the comparison data and what we
found was that um in in the original sites so about a month or so to get the data in both intervention and control
and that fell a little bit over the year or so did the study - about 22 days about three weeks but in the
intervention group it was actually only seven days seven and a half days and that was significant and the other thing
which was good was that the quality of the data was significantly better in the intervention group and then we also
found that the staff likely so much they kept complaining they wanted to finish the study and just use it everywhere and they subsequently use it implemented in
new sites and they also use it now for collecting patient weights in some cases
so the next problem was that the drug sensors we test results were done at us
at a number of larger laboratories and Peru was at that point de stablishing a
proper laboratory system for for doing these DST results when we started the project originally all of those samples
had to be sent to Boston to the Massachusetts state lab and so we would hold these things in multiple bags and
containers and so on with CDC approval but it was never a great process and we had to bring them back to Boston to
process so as they established more elaborate trees one of the things that came up was that they needed to more
rapidly process the samples so there was a study to look at more rapid methods for doing the DST s but at the same time
we was realized there was these all these problems with the information management so 10% of the results took more than 60 days to arrive at the
clinic after they had been reported in the lab about six sixths of the
patients waited over a hundred days to start treatment and these are sick people with probably multiple years of
TB with and they're shedding drug-resistant TB and infecting other people and then finally there were a lot
of duplicates I suppose it seems appropriate TB advisory
yeah and so seventeen percent were also duplicate so they were wasting the resources so what working did was to
build a system called chaski it's the chaski is an Enka runner so this guy is
the the runner who look who takes the samples between the bar trees and though
each askee was established as a module on top of the EMR and it included tools
that allow the laboratories to actually track the samples when they arrived to do quality control on the the processes
and the samples and then also to report the results to the physicians and the
physicians within get an alerting email to say that there was a new result available and so we then did a cluster
randomized controlled trial of this in over there almost 1,800 patients and
what we did was to randomize 12 clinics to the intervention and 22 to the
control initially and then that expanded as there were sub sub clinics in that group and the study lost about a year
and a half so what was interesting was that first of all the intervention health centers had 82 percent less error
rates in the DST s and eighty-seven percent less rate errors in the the result the Sarathy culture results and
this was particularly about missing results so a lot of the time the error was that you just couldn't find the
result in them in the patient's chart and in addition to that we found for example that in sixty-six percent of the
controls and 55 percent of intervention health centers they were missing about 10 percent of the paper results so this
is really fundamentally a problem of of just the workflow of the access to data and just the problems that occur with
that and so then we also looked at the effect on delays and you could see this
is pretty significant drop in the delay on getting a result from the lab now we're doing a lot better here than we
were in the past it's only 17 days whereas you could see before there were a lot higher number so things were
getting better in general but the system it did improve things both cases but what was also interesting
was that there was a significant reduction in the time to culture conversion and that's really a very key
critical clinical endpoint now I'd love to say that everything lined up perfectly and that the time that the
patient started treatment was shorter and and everything but the the treatment start team was very variable so it was
hard to really get a clear signal on that it didn't it didn't shorten very clearly but the but the culture
conversion time was significantly shorter so he did seem to improve the way that the the process was actually
managed question David it means that the patient has who has TB is when you
actually take a sputum sample and you grow it in the lab it will grow the bacteria and that means your culture
positive and so when you get started on treatment then that person goes to culture negative it's a it's a critical
event because it's one of the key milestones in curing that patient and it shows that the treatments is actually
working and what you do is you take two samples a month apart and if both of them are negative then the data
conversion is the date of the first one and so it's kind of a key event that we monitor so having done a lot of work on
this particular area of MDR TB and also worked on an equivalent system which we
built for HIV management in Haiti we kind of recognized that there were some real issues around having specialized
vertical systems and we needed to think about doing something but with more kind of general purpose and could apply to
lots of different kinds of diseases so we needed really a system an EMR system or a generic medical record system that
was simple to set up that would work on multiple computing platforms you know Windows and Linux and maybe the Mac and
then subsequently on on our mobile devices we needed local users to be able
to modify the system add forms and reports and generally be able to actually customize it to their own
requirements rather than being really dependent on outside expertise and we wanted this to be web-based but also
designed so you could run it on a smaller device such as a laptop in a clinic if you didn't have connectivity
you needed to support open standards and these are really a critical thing which we'll come back to but
things like hl7 or health 7/7 which is a communication standard for health information between different systems
like a for example a medical record system and a lab system low ink which is
a coding system for lab data and sno-med and ICT icd-10 which is pretty a system
for coding diagnosis icd-10 is used by the whu-oh and a lot of international agencies and sno-med and sunbeds CT
which is the modern version of that is used by a lot of US hospitals and we also wanted the system to be open source
so that we could share that work of development both with our colleagues in the US but also around the world and
that the ownership of the system would be then have really handed over to everybody who used it so instead of
saying here's some free software but you have to ask us to maintain it we'd really hand over the whole system and
the expertise and the training to really develop and use that mmm so out of this
came a system called openmrs or the open medical record system the open EMR open
EHR unfortunately had gone at that point so we had their number 3 but that was a
system which was originally conceived by a couple of colleagues of ours at the regula Street Institute in Indiana who
are working with their colleagues in Ampath in Kenya which is a project in western Kenya which I'll talk about more and they've been thinking about this and
building some prototypes when we got together and we were talking about how we needed to build something based upon
what we've been doing in Haiti with the HIV EMR system and so we decided to collaborator to actually build a new
system which we started at beginning of 2005 and this is a system which is
designed to be very kind of open both in terms of open source but it also supports open standards and it has a
concept dictionary to manage the data which I'll come back to it's modular so
that you can actually take the core system but you can also build additional piece of software and plug them into it
so that you can have people who have a limited experience experimenting trying things out and trying building new modules and then as they get better at
it being able to really extend the system it was released as an open source system in 2007 and that's kind of
important because there's a lot of people who talk about open source when it comes down to it it's really hard to get the source code so I assure
you since April 2007 our source code has been fully available and we're very very
passionate about that issue and one of the things that people talk a lot about open sources you know who actually
develops these systems and who's responsible for for dealing with problems and bug fixes and so on so we
have a core team of paid programmers one of whom is here Rita who's been working
on the system actually for about a year and a half an hour in Rwanda and doing some of the training of the random
programmers and so that that team really is responsible for for managing a lot of
the issues but we have a lot of volunteer programmers now both individuals and also some companies so
the concept dictionary is a simple idea with lots of very interesting and sometimes complicated manifestations so
the idea is that instead of having a database where you build a separate table for each different set of data or
I'd say a new form or a new kind of lab date like lab test you have a dictionary and you can enter new concepts in that
dictionary and they can be numeric in which case you have a range of numeric values they can be coded and this as in
this case where what you have is the main concept which is functional review of symptoms and then a list of other
concepts which are really the like a drop-down menu that you can then code this the result with they can also be
used for drug orders and you can also enter free text in concepts and the idea
of this is that it gives people the flexibility to add and extend the system but also it has other advantages like
you can develop a score data set for example for a grubs and TB as we've been doing and then you can share that with
other organizations so people are actually using the same codes and you can clearly map reports and analyses
between the different sites so it's really an important issue and this can then be mapped to other coding systems
and we've done this our colleague from millennium villages project Andy Kanter who actually be talking later on in this
course has done this for sno-med and ICD and other coding systems the openmrs
communities is based around a mailing list and we have this website and this is us at one of our
meetings of about 120 people which we've had in South Africa for about five years in a row now I'm getting everyone
together to work on the crow crow missile system and also do a lot of programming this is an example of then
taking openmrs which is a core system and a common platform for building um our systems and then actually focusing
on a particular disease within that core platform and so in a way it's kind of taking a full circle it's a platform
which can support primary care HIV TB heart disease whatever but in this case
we've customized it to make it easier for people managing MDR TB patients to have the tools that they would have had in the old system so you can see they
have a list of reports here and then you can enter you search for patients here and then this is an example that mark
Goodrich one of the programmers in our team here has been working on to visualize the data for MDR TB and it's
kind of it's sort of based on a long series of different experiments over the years with our other systems you can see
that you have the different lab results here these are smear results with patient there's a cultural result which
is positive this is drug sensitivity test results showing resistance to eyes on eyes it and ethambutol
and rifampicin and this is a timeline for the drugs or we call a drug a gram showing that the patient is taking this
particular set of drugs during that time and that there's no resistance for the drugs that they're taking according to this result another really interesting
thing that happened after we developed this system for MDR TB based on our cameras was that amir khan and his group
in Pakistan in Karachi decided they wanted to use this system so they took the system they did a mash up excuse me
a mash up with Google Maps and so you can then see all the patient locations in Karachi and then the patients who
have green their health care workers have texted that they actually received their directly the therapy within the
last 48 hours and then when you click on one these people you can pull up this record which is that from the open area
system it's another way of viewing the smearing capture results so it's kind of an interesting mix and this was something that they took on and were
able to do because it was open source they were able to take the system and customize it and build on that
so opening racism being growing rather rapidly not all of these sites are
clinical but about a month ago we did a survey to see how many sites were definitely using the system for clinical
care and there are at least 24 countries in which there are projects using the system for clinical care
many of these are development sites and many of these we don't really know what people are up to and last year about a hundred and ten countries downloaded the
system so we don't really kind know who is doing water with those ones question I mean we wondered about having a system
that asked you if you can sort of send a message back saying hey I'm running now but it's in the way it's kind of a
little bit it seems a little bit like I sort of you know keeping tabs on people so it's a difficult question exactly and
so what this is doing this is actually used to Africa here is Rwanda which is where we have a
lot of our sites 21 sites there this is in western Kenya el Durrett Uganda down
in Malawi we have site in Nino and some other sites down in in the east coast of
Tanzania milling in village project sites and West Africa and then we look at Rwanda itself which is where I would
do a lot of my work you can see this is the board around here like Kiva which I
had the good pleasure of being in two weeks ago um and our site in quavo is
just in this area here near the acog era of Game Reserve so we've been working in
Rwanda for about five years now it's a small African country with about nine million people very densely
populated and very heavily rural although Kigali the capital is actually quite quite rapidly developing so it
seems like it's better off than it it really is it she'd really rapid economic growth over the last few years but still
has really big health problems these numbers are a probably a couple of years out of date I wasn't able to get the exact recent ones which have improved a
bit particularly maternal and infant mortality rates but they're still you can see very high numbers for for these two figures particular
maternal mortality and very low median income even though you wouldn't think this you wouldn't think that when you're
in Kigali so currently we're using up numerous in about twenty one health
centers we're actually expanding at the moment to another five or ten these are sites
that pH is supporting with the government in addition we collect data on HIV initially and now on TB and heart
disease and we're expanding it to primary care we have about sixteen thousand patients trapped in the system
at the moment that number is going up pretty quickly now that we started registering new patients in primary care and we have a team of what we call
rendered data officers who do the data entry from paper forms and that's usually the way people are entering data
into systems like openmrs and many sites actually have their own servers now because the internet access is really
unreliable and it uses satellite internet so it's got a high latency and so what we're doing is we have a system
running locally but then we have some tools for synchronizing that data to a central site so that in the background
you're getting a copy of that data and you're also pushing back the data on things like cd4 counts and that's really
important so you the lab data which is really critical for managing HIV patients is getting to the peripheral sites this is an example of some really
kind of alerts and summaries that we've been printing for our staff for about three and a half years now and these are
generated so this is a row you know for the pay each patient has a row here and what we're doing is we're actually
showing the most recent weights Merson recent cd4 counts and if there's
a problem we can have actually activate an alert such as you know this patient needs a cd4 count is out of date and
this data is really important in fact in helping to keep track of insulin Patrick
uh-huh
so even if you wouldn't I will actually come back to that in about five minutes because I've got a couple of things I
wanted to set that up with it's a very relevant question which we've actually been bumping into so one of the question
you want to know was how effective was the EMR system in supporting some key aspects of care for HIV patients so
Cheryl Amoroso who is our project manager and leads the EMR projects in Rwanda looked at this question about
whether the physicians had access to the latest cd4 count so the way they did this was that when you fill out a page
paper follow-up form the physician is asked to record what they believe is the most recent cd4 count and so then we
looked at whether there were delays in getting access to that so we said why don't we implement this new lab system
which will allow the laboratory to enter the cd4 counts more efficiently into the EMR system and then that will drive them
towards those alerts we just I just showed you and see if that had an impact so we looked at this question of cd4
counts that were done in the last 60 days that were not available or not known to the physician when they saw the
patient we found that about a quarter of the time that they actually had an out to date cd4 count once we'd implemented
the lab system and with the paper printouts we've got that down to about 16% which is you know pretty good
improvement but it's still not good enough obviously and you have to think about the kind of environment working in all the different clinics the logistics
are trying to get between those clinics and to actually deliver paper and then manage it all so the question then was
how do we actually prove that further so what we did was then to set up so that mmm the conditions can actually look at
a summary of the patients so we have the summary of HIV patients and several of
the clinics now have access to this in the ID clinic where the HIV patients are managed and what they see is a little
summary here which has basically a list of any adverse events recent symptoms
the drug regimen the patient's taking is try immune and try Methvin self and the
Sox are sold prophylaxis and then here's some key lab data like the cd4 counts
